 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project i Definitions Contraceptive Prevalence Rate: The percentage of married women in reproductive ages who are using (or whose husbands are using) any form of contraception at any given point in time. Crude Birth Rate: The number of births per 1,000 population in a given year. Crude Death Rate: The number of deaths per 1,000 population in a given year. Dependency Ratio: The ratio of the economically dependent part of the population to the productive part, arbitrarily defined as the ratio of the young (under 15 years of age) and the elderly (those 65 years of age and older) to the working age population (those 15-64 years of age). Incidence Rate: The number of new cases of a disease which occur in a population during a specified period of time. Usually expressed as the number of cases per 1,000 persons. Infant Mortality Rate: The number of deaths of infants under one year of age in a given year per 1,000 live births in that year. Life Expectancy at Birth: The average number of years a newborn would live if current age/sex-specific mortality trends prevailing at the time of birth were maintained. Morbidity Rate: The frequency of disease in a population in a given period. Prevalence Rate: The total number of people affected by a disease estimated either at a specific time (point prevalence) or over a stated period (period prevalence expressed per 1,000 population). In case of low figures, prevalence is expressed per 100,000 population. Rate of Population Growth: The natural increase of the population in a given year, adjusted for (net) migration, and expressed as a percentage of the base population. Total Fertility Rate: The average number of children that would be born alive to a woman during her lifetime if she passed through her childbearing years conforming to the age-specific fertility rates of a given year. Average Occupancy Rate: Number of hospital patient-days/(number of beds multiplied by 365).

 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project iii BURUNDI SECOND HEALTH AND POPULATION PROJECT Credit and Project Summary Borrower : Republic of Burundi Beneficiary : Ministry of Public Health (MOPH) Amount : SDR 14.3 million (US$21.3 million equivalent) Terms : Standard IDA terms with 40 years maturity Project Description: The objectives of the proposed project are to improve the health status of Burundi's population and contribute to sustainable per capita income growth by slowing population growth, thus reducing population pressures on resources. It aims to help increase the availability, quality and efficiency of health services and make them more responsive to the public's expectations. Together with the contributions of other donors, the proposed project would constitute a coherent program to support the government in developing strategies to address the most critical sector issues. Specific objectives are to: (i) strengthen MOPH's capacity to design and implement key sector reforms; (ii) improve the efficiency and affordability of health care delivery in rural areas; (iii) contribute to reducing population growth and maternal and child mortality rates; and (iv) promote beneficial health and family planning behaviors. The project would support policies and investments designed to: (a) strengthen MOPH capacity to effect reforms in human resource management (including reducing the shortage of health personnel), hospital management autonomy, health financing, quality of health services, and maintenance; (b) strengthen service delivery in five out of 15 provinces by supporting basic health services and rehabilitating nine hospitals; (c) implement the maternal and child and family planning (MCH/FP) policy; and (d) improve sectoral information, education and communication (IEC) activities. Benefits: The rehabilitation of health services and the implementation of key sector reforms would contribute to improving the overall quality of health services, while making them more accessible to the poor at an affordable cost. The project is therefore expected to help reduce mortality and morbidity rates in Burundi. In addition, the successful implementation of the family planning policy and IEC activities would help Burundi reduce its population growth rate and promote beneficial health behaviors among the population. The project would be expected to have the following principal outcomes: (i) quality of health services in the project area would be judged satisfactory by 60 percent *of the beneficiaries surveyed at the end of the project; (ii) management autonomy would have been introduced in all public hospitals,

Risks: This is a project with above-average risk. The main risk relates to the country's unstable political situation; to address this risk, the project has been designed in a flexible manner, so that some components could be implemented even during a crisis and the project's intended benefits could be safeguarded; for example, hospital rehabilitation, implementation of MCH/PF and IEC activities, and strengthening of hospital management autonomy and service quality could be implemented first in the safest provinces. However, implementation of some sector reforms (particularly health financing and staff redeployment) could be delayed, since they involve political decisions and actions that may not be feasible in a crisis. In case of a continuous crisis, the project would be restructured substantially as needed during the mid-term review. Other risks relate to: (i) the population's response to MOPH's reforms; to address this risk, a beneficiary assessment has been conducted and the results used during project preparation; similar assessments and quality surveys would be carried out throughout project implementation; (ii) the institutional weaknesses of MOPH, since MOPH's commitment to the reforms exceeds its current capacity; to address this risk, project support would include strong capacity-building activities in areas where MOPH lacks expertise; project implementation would be divided among a number of different directorates within MOPH, while PCT procurement and financing functions would be strengthened; and, the project conditions and covenants would enable close monitoring of project implementation and development performance; (iii) the weak human resource base, especially the lack of qualified health personnel; to address this risk, the project would help MOPH reduce the overall deficiency of personnel, in terms of both quantity and quality; and (iv) insufficient MOPH funding, which may jeopardize improvement of health services, especially drug availablity; to address this risk, Government agreed at negotiations that its proposals for health sector investments and budgetary allocations would be reviewed by IDA annually, and that the draft budget would incorporate IDA's comments before its approval by the Council of Ministers. Environmental Risks: No environmental risks are foreseen. Economic Rate of Return: Not applicable.

 I. SECTORAL CONTEXT A. ECONOMIC, POLITICAL AND SOCIAL CONTEXT 1.1 Economic and political context. With a population of about 5.8 million and an area of 27,834 km2, Burundi has the second highest population density in Africa after its neighbor Rwanda. The population comprises two main ethnic groups, the Hutus (85%) and the Tutsis (14%). Despite demographic pressure (3.1% growth per year) on already constrained land, urbanization is limited; 94% of the population is still rural. Burundi's GDP per capita is one of the lowest in the world, at US$180 in 1993. 1.2 Agriculture is Burundi's main economic activity, contributing half of GDP and over 80% of employment and export earnings. Prior to the 1993 political crisis, Burundi was one of the few African countries self-sufficient in food. Coffee is the most important cash crop, accounting for 70% of merchandise exports. The secondary sector is still small (equivalent to 19% of GDP and 11% of exports) and dominated by the public sector. After 10 years of good performance following independence (real GDP growth averaged 5.5% a year during 1962-1972), Burundi's economic and financial situation began to deteriorate from 1972 onwards because of world economic developments and ethnic violence, and took a further turn for the worse in 1981-1984. The Government launched an adjustment program in 1986 and began to move towards a more liberal economic and political regime. Real GDP growth averaged 4.8% during 1987-1989. However, the 1990-1993 period was marked by backtracking on austerity measures; real GDP growth slowed to an average of 1.4% per annum, with negative growth in 1993. 1.3 The first free elections held in June 1993 resulted in the election of the first Hutu president and the acquisition of legislative power by the political party FRODEBU. However, three months after his inauguration (October 1993), the president and other key FRODEBU leaders were assassinated in a coup attempt led by a small group within the army. This event gave rise to an outbreak of violence that left at least 50,000 dead and resulted in the migration of about 800,000 persons to neighboring countries. Many of them returned in the spring of 1994 following the outbreak of larger-scale violence in neighboring Rwanda, triggered by the airplane crash on April 6, 1994 that killed the presidents of both Rwanda and Burundi. While Burundi succeeded in averting renewed widespread massacres, these events aggravated long-standing ethnic tensions and made it difficult for the two ethnic groups to reach a consensus on modalities of power-sharing. Sporadic violence has continued to occur in parts of the country, perpetuating a sense of insecurity. 1.4 In September 1994, 12 of the country's 13 political parties signed a power-sharing agreement ("Convention de Gouvernement"), which is to remain in effect for four years, an interim period during which major constitutional and political reforms are to be discussed and agreed upon. On October 1, 1994, a new interim president was sworn in and a new Government, headed by the former prime minister, was formed. In March 1995, there was a further change of Prime Minister and some Cabinet posts. The political situation remains fragile and needs to be consolidated, in part through rapid and tangible improvement in the economic and social conditions of the population. For that purpose, the Government has endorsed an Emergency Recovery Program (ERP), prepared with IDA assistance in the last semester of 1994, which aims to address Burundi's most pressing social needs, and set the stage for restoring long-term economic growth potential (para.2. 1).
 2 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project 1.5 Poverty and social conditions. While overall destruction of public infrastructure was limited to communal buildings and small roads and bridges, the 1993 crisis caused a sharp drop in both food production and the delivery of social services. In addition, the high number of refugees and displaced persons exacerbated the human hardship of the crisis, in terms of the breakdown of social bonds, widespread theft, loss and destruction of property. At present, 200,000 refugees from Burundi still live in Tanzania and Zaire, while another 600,000 continue to live in displaced-person camps within Burundi. These factors have together contributed to an increase in poverty, which was already widespread before the crisis. The latest poverty estimates (June 1994) classify 57% of the rural population and 59% of the urban population as poor, up from 36% and 42%, respectively, in 1990. 1.6 Burundi's education and health sectors were paralyzed for a year from October 1993 because of the insecurity prevailing throughout the country. Large numbers of personnel fled to safer zones while others were killed, leaving schools and health facilities inadequately staffed. Equipment, supplies and vehicles were vandalized or stolen and national distribution channels broke down. In the education sector, the number of teachers dropped by about 20% in primary schools and 40% in secondary schools. As of September 1994, many primary schools in rural areas had still not reopened and enrollments had dropped by 25% from the level of September 1993. 1.7 The national health system has relied almost exclusively on international emergency aid since the crisis began. The substantial flow of humanitarian relief (which amounted to US$85 million in 1994) and the efficiency of aid-coordination mechanisms managed by the MOPH and donors helped to prevent major epidemics and serious health problems on a national scale. Nutritional and health care as well as emergency food aid have been provided in the hardest hit areas and in displaced-person camps by international organizations (UNICEF, International Red Cross, WHO) and numerous NGOs. With progress in the resolution of the politico-institutional crisis of October 1993, the national health system has started to operate again. However, it faces serious operational constraints that will require immediate reforms. B. HEALTH ST'ATUS AND DELIVERY OF HEALTH SERVICES 1.8 Health Status. Prior to the crisis, Burundi's health status was comparable to the average for Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) despite the country's extremely low GDP per capita. Infant mortality and under-five mortality rates were estimated at 110 per 1,000 and 173 per 1,000 respectively. Life expectancy (47 years) was slightly below the Sub-Saharan average. Over time, respiratory diseases, malaria and diarrhea/dysentery have been the main causes of morbidity and mortality in the general population (Annex 1). The malaria epidemic has been worsening because of increasing chloroquine resistance and the scarcity of other types of malaria treatment. Women's health problems and mortality have been especially related to complications during pregnancy and delivery. The magnitude of the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Burundi has become evident only recently. With urban adult HIV infection rates estimated at 15-20% and rural rates between I and 2%, the AIDS epidemic is a threat not only to public health but also to the socio-economic development of the country (para. 1.31). Major disruptions in the delivery of health services and public health programs during the crisis have had a negative impact on the country's health status, although it is difficult to assess its scope and magnitude. Chronic malnutrition among children under five has risen from 26% (1987) to around 40%. Acute malnutrition has increased to 10% among the most vulnerable groups of the population, particularly among pregnant and breast-feeding women. The crisis has contributed to an increase of AIDS and sexually-transmitted diseases (STD) in the camps

This foreshadows a further spread of the AIDS epidemic upon the return of these individuals. 1.9 Health services. The network of health facilities in Burundi is fairly extensive, providing better health coverage to the population than in most Sub-Saharan countries. 80% of the population live within five kilometers of a health center, although access is difficult in mountainous areas. Health services are organized administratively at four levels: central, 15 provinces, 25 health "secteurs" and 114 communes. Public health services include: one military hospital, one teaching hospital, one clinic, and two specialized centers (for psychiatry and tuberculosis), all located in the capital (Bujumbura); 26 hospitals located at the provincial (14) and "secteur" (12) levels; and 270 health centers. Private non-profit religious institutions run a fourth of the country's health services (10 hospitals and 70 health centers). Religious health facilities are well-managed and adequately supplied, and provide services of good quality, for which they charge higher user fees than public facilities. In contrast, the quality of services provided at public health facilities is poor, due to chronic shortages of essential drugs and supplies, lack of qualified personnel and equipment, and poor management. Buildings are also in a poor condition. As a consequence, despite their higher population coverage, Burundi's public health facilities have low utilization rates that are similar to those of Sub-Saharan Africa; the average bed occupancy rate is only 51% for hospitals, although it may sometimes reach 85% for the hospitals in the capital. 1.10 MOPH started a few years ago to address the issues of poor quality and management of public health services. Rehabilitation of most of the country's health centers has been under way since 1989, with support from donors, including IDA under the ongoing Population and Health Project (Credit 1862-BI) which has rehabilitated 43 health centers; these efforts began to show some results prior to the crisis. In comparison, the problems of the rural hospital network, whose role in primary health care is crucial but often neglected, have yet to be adequately addressed (para. 1.29). In order to improve management in public hospitals, the Government has introduced management autonomy in nine facilities, and intends to extend it to all public hospitals by the year 1997. Autonomous hospitals receive global budgetary allocations from the Government and are allowed to retain revenues from user fees (in contrast to other hospitals which must forward the proceeds to the treasury). 1.11 Impact of the crisis on the delivery of health services and programs. Public health infrastructure did not suffer major physical damage during the crisis: only 45 out of 270 health centers and one hospital need some minor rehabilitation. However, a lot of equipment and nearly all vehicles have been vandalized or stolen and have to be replaced. During the crisis, the system suffered from major operational constraints. Most public health facilities were no longer in a position to offer services because of the breakdown of supply channels and the departure of many health staff. The national pharmaceutical depot stopped supplying drugs to public health facilities and budgetary allocations were suspended for several months. Public health programs ceased to operate as well. Immunization coverage, which had been high by SSA standards (reaching 90% in some instances), is known to have declined substantially in the hardest hit areas. International relief aid compensated for the breakdown of the national health system. International NGOs ran public health services and programs in the provinces and districts worst affected by the crisis. With the return to greater stability, the national system has again become functional: the drug supply system has started to operate again and public health facilities have received budgetary allocations. However, the acute shortage of personnel remains a serious constraint. The MOPH estimates that at present 24 health centers (9%) are closed, three operate without any qualified personnel and 72 (27%) operate with only one qualified employee; one hospital is closed; five rural hospitals (17%)

Even prior to the crisis, Burundi had an overall shortage of health staff, both clinical and managerial. The total number of physicians was estimated at 337 in 1991, out of which 110 were expatriates. Although this total represented a significant improvement over the level in 1987 (206 physicians), the ratio of 17,210 persons per physician was still below WHO norms. In comparison, the number of paramedical personnel was more adequate, with four paramedical schools graduating 200 students per year. However, shortages of health personnel were acute outside the capital because of the uneven distribution of personnel: 60% of all medical staff and 95% of physician specialists were concentrated in Bujumbura. The crisis affected the physician situation more adversely than that of paramedical personnel. The shortage of physicians became heightened with the departure of most of the Rwandese physicians (mainly Tutsi refugees since the 1970s), who returned to Rwanda after fighting ended in mid-1994. Many paramedical personnel in Burundi's hardest hit areas left for safer places within the country, where they eventually found work in other public health facilities. 1.13 Health administration. The MOPH is responsible for operating the public health system. In 1985, it decentralized certain administrative functions to the provincial level: 15 provincial bureaus (BPS), each headed by a provincial medical director, were to coordinate health programs (such as immunization and malaria control), IEC activities, as well as drug supply and staffing, and supervise health facilities. However, provincial bureaus had neither the staff nor the means to carry out even a minimum level of operations, and sector activity remained overly centralized. Prior to the crisis, MOPH intended to strengthen the capacity of the provincial bureaus and provide them with the required resources (through support from the European Union); the impact of the crisis on the health system has convinced MOPH of the urgent need to implement such reforms. MOPH has recently taken two important steps in that direction: its organization was restructured to reflect the new authority given to the 15 BPS as well as the autonomous hospitals (Annex 2); and budgetary allocations for the BPS were specifically identified in the 1995 health budget. Much has yet to be done to assess the full implications of the decentralization in terms of staffing and financial needs, and to define the new roles of the administration and autonomous health facilities (para. 1.27). Beginning in 1991, the health information system was strengthened with the assistance of UNICEF, USAID and the ongoing IDA-supported Population and Health Project. This system, managed by the Bureau of Epidemiological Statistics (EPISTAT), is now fairly well organized and provides good health data. Feedback is provided through a monthly bulletin which is sent to provinces and "secteurs". 1.14 Health Financing. Although available data on health expenditures are neither complete nor fully reliable, total health expenditure in Burundi could be roughly estimated at US$7 to 8 per capita in 1991 (latest data available), which was equivalent to 3 to 4% of GDP. Main sources of financing include: (i) public expenditures (around 70% of total health expenditure), with central Government expenditures accounting for only 25% of total expenditure and external aid for about 45%; (ii) a health insurance scheme for the civil service (around 16% of the total); (iii) private pharmaceutical expenditures, excluding those reimbursed by civil service health insurance (7%); (iv) total health expenditures of the religious network of health facilities (5%); and (v) cost recovery at public health facilities (2%).

Compared to other SSA countries, Burundi ranks among those with a medium level of Government health expenditure, as a percentage of both GDP and total Government expenditure. However, in terms of Government health expenditure per capita (both recurrent and capital), which amounted to US$2.13/capita in 1993, Burundi ranks in the lowest group of countries, reflecting its poverty. MOPH recurrent expenditures accounted for 5 to 6% of the Government's recurrent expenditures during 1984-1994 (Annex 3, Table 1); their share of GDP at constant prices gradually increased to nearly 1% in 1993. There are no major imbalances in the distribution of MOPH recurrent expenditures (Annex 3, Table 2): personnel expenditure accounted for 59% of MOPH's recurrent budget in 1991 and declined to 47% in 1993 (reflecting the elimination of salaries for the autonomous hospitals which are included in their global budget). Drugs and laboratory and surgical supplies are the second largest source of expenditure, accounting for 21% of MOPH's recurrent budget in 1993. Other expenditures, including those for equipment and vehicle maintenance, are inadequate and have increased at a slower rate than the overall budget; they are mainly made by hospitals. 1.16 External aid financed 86% of capital expenditures for the health sector in the fifth Five-Year Plan (1988-1992). A 1993-1995 Public Expenditure Program (PEP) was prepared by MOPH prior to the crisis. Total public expenditures planned for the health sector in 1993 were significant, equivalent to US$6.4/capita or 3.4% of GDP. However, major programs were delayed and could not be implemented due to the crisis. The Government has prepared a draft Public Investment Program (PIP) for 1995-1997, which still needs to be refined to take into account all donors' interventions and is currently being reassessed. It was agreed during negotiations that the 1996 recurrent budget and 1996-1998 PIP for the health sector will be submitted to IDA by October 30, 1995 (para. 3.15). 1.17 Insurance and user fees. The total expenditures of the health insurance scheme for the civil service, managed by the "Mutuelle de la Fonction Publique" (MFP), were equivalent to 75% of MOPH recurrent expenditures in 1991 (latest data available). This contributory scheme, which started in 1980, provides good health coverage for around 400,000 civil servants and their direct dependents (7% of the total population). Benefits cover the costs of ambulatory and in-patient care in public and private non profit health facilities as well as prescribed drugs. For the first time in 1991, MFP did not realize a profit. The major cause of MFP's deteriorating performance has been the growing amount of reimbursements for prescribed drugs, due to the increased frequency of fraud (use of benefits for uninsured individuals), high prices of pharmaceuticals sold in private pharmacies, and poor prescription practices. MFP's expenditures are likely to rise significantly with the introduction of management autonomy in all public hospitals, which will then have a strong incentive to bill it for services provided to its beneficiaries. In September 1993 (just before the October events), MFP contracted consultant services to help design strategies to address the main causes of its financial difficulties. With the return to greater stability in 1995, MFP will be in a position to further elaborate on these strategies. Since 1983, private employers in the formal sector have been responsible for 100% of the medical expenses incurred by their employees (around 20,000 salaried workers) and their families. The CAM was introduced in 1984 as an annual pre-payment scheme for health care, entitling the card holder and direct dependents to free medical care and drugs in public health centers and hospitals. Despite its low price of FBu 500 (US$2 equivalent), unchanged since 1984, only 20 to 25% of the population is estimated to have bought the card in any given year. Several reasons explain this low rate of utilization. First, the purchase of the CAM does not guarantee access to services in practice, since drugs are often lacking at public health facilities. As revenues from CAM sales and user fees are not retained at health centers but returned to communes, cost recovery has not contributed to improving the quality of services. According to 1991 data, only 14% of CAM proceeds was, on average, used by communes to finance recurrent costs of health centers (Annex 3, Table 3). Second, given the low level of user fees for ambulatory care, the card does not offer any significant advantage, except for expensive hospital care. Indeed, as the CAM system has no qualifying period, the card tends to be purchased just prior to hospitalization, resulting in considerable savings in certain cases. Third, non-profit health facilities do not accept the CAM since they are not reimbursed for the services provided. For this reason, families who use private services (around 30% of the population) may never purchase the card. 1.19 User fees have existed in the public health sector since 1983, for patients not holding a CAM card and for MFP-insured patients who have to pay 20% of total fees ("ticket moderateur"). Proceeds from user fees at public health centers and hospitals are very low, equivalent to I and 4% of MOPH's recurrent expenditures, respectively. The reasons are both the low fees themselves and the lack of incentives for public health facilities to seek payment of charges, since proceeds are returned either to communes or to the treasury (in the case of non-autonomous hospitals). Higher user fees are charged by the non-profit sector, on a fee schedule agreed with MOPH. Health facilities managed by the Catholic organization CARITAS had an average cost recovery ratio of 77% in 1991, with health and maternity centers having a much higher ratio (94%) than hospitals (49%). However, grants received from foreign missions and salaries of foreign nurses often are not included in the numbers. 1.20 Drug Supply. Drugs are supplied by both the public sector and the private sector as well as religious organizations. The Government-run national office of pharmacy (ONAPHA) represents the country's only local pharmaceutical production operation and supplies 48 pharmaceutical products (mostly essential drugs). ONAPHA is currently attached to the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, with MOPH as its main client. Due to its poor efficiency, ONAPHA was on the list of public enterprises to be privatized under the Bank's (Third) Structural Adjustment Credit for Burundi (June 1992). Although such an action did not take place prior to the crisis, it will be reconsidered when the privatization program is reestablished on the Government's agenda. Drugs in the public sector are procured by the national pharmaceutical depot and distributed to the 15 BPS, which are responsible for allocating them to health facilities. In an attempt to rationalize drug distribution and reduce drug shortages, MOPH started in 1991 to allocate drugs to each health 2 The INSS, established in 1962, covers pension, disability and death benefits for some 70,000 workers in the private sector. parastatal agencies and the armed forces (the civil servants receive pensions from a non-contributory fund).

Despite this improvement, health facilities still face frequent shortages of drugs, estimated at three months of consumption per year according to field observations and studies. This is primarily due to insufficient drug allocations (MOPH's drug budget was a low US$0.38/capita in 1993) and to poor management and procurement practices at the central depot. During project preparation, MOPH designed measures to improve drug availability and management, for implementation under the proposed project. However, the European Union has since committed to financing such measures, beginning in 1995 (Annex 4). It will assist MOPH in: (i) developing an essential drug policy; (ii) strengthening management and procurement at the pharmaceutical depot; (iii) improving drug management and use in public health facilities, by setting up drug management tools and training health staff in proper prescription practices; and (iv) later (mid- 1996), transforming the depot into an autonomous unit charged with the procurement of essential drugs that are competitively priced, for subsequent sale to health facilities in the public and non profit private sectors, and decentralizing drug distribution. 1.21 Information, Education and Communication (IEC). The ongoing IDA-financed Population and Health Project (Cr. 1862-BI) has helped introduce IEC activities within MOPH, by providing support to the then existing Health Education Bureau that had undertaken some activities in traditional health education. IEC activities are presently carried out by the Health Education Unit (HEU) located in the Hygiene and Prevention Directorate of the MOPH; its mandate is to plan, coordinate and control the quality of IEC activities. In the past, HEU has been successful in informing and educating the population about public health problems and motivating them to change their behavior: (i) it contributed to the increase in vaccination coverage in the late 1980's and to the control of the 1992 meningitis epidemic; (ii) it has assisted the National AIDS Control Program in increasing AIDS awareness among the Burundian population; and (iii) it has produced high quality (even award winning) informational materials. However, increased demands from the various programs have greatly diminished HEU's efficiency during the last three years (para. 1.32). The need for additional staff proved a particular bottleneck, given Burundi's weak IEC capacity and HEU's limited pool of adequately trained and qualified management staff. C. KEY SECTOR ISSUES 1.22 Main sector issues are the following: (i) shortage of health personnel; (ii) lack of performance and equity of existing financing mechanisms; (iii) poor management and institutional capacity; (iv) inadequacy of the rural hospital network; (v) rapid population growth; (vi) a major AIDS epidemic; and (vii) limited IEC capacities. 1.23 Shortage of health personnel. The reasons for the current deficit of physicians and paramedicals are divergent and call for tailored strategies, which will be developed, starting in 1995, by MOPH with donor support, including IDA (Annex 4). Even prior to the crisis, Burundi was short of physicians and quite dependent upon expatriates (especially Rwandese), who accounted for a third of all physicians in the public sector. Given the current shortage of physicians at public hospitals (para. 1.11) and the low output of graduates from the medical school (20 per year), it will take years before Burundi can meet the minimum norms required to make the system work adequately. MOPH will have to design, along with the Ministry of Higher Education, strategies to increase both the output of physicians and the relevance of their training, in order to meet sector needs more quickly and adequately. The main strategy will be to reduce the high dropout rate at the medical school: out of 70 students accepted each year, only 20 graduate. A study done in 1993 with the support of the
 8 Burundi. Second Health and Population Project ongoing IDA project showed that the dropout rate between the first and third years of the medical curriculum was more than 60%. In the short term, however, MOPH will have to recruit expatriate physicians to meet the most urgent needs for clinical physicians, especially in provincial and "secteur" hospitals. Most donors have agreed to finance short-term expatriate technical assistance until the number of national physicians available on the market is sufficient. 1.24 Compared to the scarcity of physicians, the current shortage of paramedicals is more directly related to Burundi's crisis. The extent of the current deficit in many health facilities (para. 1.1 1) calls for the urgent development and implementation of strategies aimed at providing minimum services and restoring the confidence of the population. MOPH intends to develop various short term strategies, including redeploying existing health personnel on the basis of their individual preferences and health personnel needs. MOPH has also decided, with the agreement of the Ministry of Finance, to grant travel-related allowances to around 300 staff who would accept temporary assignments (up to five days a week) in insecure areas experiencing high deficits. With support from UNDP, the Government started in 1992 to design civil service reform, but efforts were stopped due to the crisis; given the current political situation in Burundi, implementation of such reform within the next few years is unlikely. However, the introduction of management autonomy in all public hospitals will provide financial incentives for health personnel, since such hospitals could recruit contractual staff under their own salary scales and provide financial incentives to civil servant staff. These developments would, in turn, pose new challenges for MOPH, to be addressed in its policy framework for hospital management autonomy (Annex 5); for example, MOPH will have to define the extent of power that the board of directors of an autonomous hospital will enjoy in defining personnel policies (including salaries, hiring, laying off, promotion, training, etc.). 1.25 Lack of performance and equity of existing financing mechanisms. Existing financing mechanisms for public health services have failed to improve service quality and ensure equitable access. The vast majority of the population lives in rural areas and has access to public health services that are inexpensive but of poor quality. As a result, rural patients have invariably to buy expensive drugs and medical supplies from private suppliers, or pay relatively high fees for drugs and medical services at private religious health facilities, if able to access and afford them. In comparison, salaried workers from the public and private sectors, who are largely urban dwellers, benefit from good health insurance coverage financed (at high cost) by their employers. Urban dwellers also have access to better quality services, especially at those hospitals the quality of which improved significantly when they became autonomous (because of their capability to retain revenues and the solvency of their insured patients). Urgent reforms are needed to: (i) increase the sector's overall level of resources and ensure adequate financing for health facilities, especially in rural areas; (ii) improve access to affordable, quality health services for the vast majority of the population; and (iii) strengthen existing planning tools, such as PEPs and PIPs. 1.26 Increased resources will be generated by enabling the health sector to retain and manage proceeds from the CAM and user fees, and raising the sector's overall performance in terms of revenue mobilization. Improved equity will be ensured by increasing the quality of public services in rural areas, maintaining the affordability of the CAM, and establishing adequate mechanisms to subsidize the CAM for the poor. Since 1992, both the majority and opposition parties in Burundi have been strongly committed to introducing such reforms, including the eventual establishment of nationwide health insurance for the rural population. Government commitment remains strong today, as these reforms are essential to building national reconciliation (by improving equity and transparency in resource allocation). To quickly ensure access to health services for the poor and needy, the Government has included in the 1995 Emergency Recovery Program (ERP) the
 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project 9 financing of two social funds: one of FBu 215 million (US$0.9 million) to subsidize the CAM for the displaced persons and refugees (through a temporary mechanism to be designed and managed by the ministry in charge of them); and one of FBu 80 million (US$0.3 million) to subsidize the CAM for indigents (through a mechanism to be designed by MOPH). 1.27 Poor management and institutional capacity. MOPH is strongly committed to restoring public health services and ensuring their adequate functioning. However, the overcentralization of the health system, weak institutional capacity at the rural levels, and overall lack of qualified personnel pose obstacles to the success of needed reforms. Aware of these issues, MOPH has already taken some important steps towards decentralizing key management functions, by deciding to grant managerial autonomy to both the central pharmaceutical depot and the public hospitals, decentralize drug distribution, and strengthen administration at peripheral levels (by giving them more responsibilities and resources). However, MOPH has not yet fully assessed the implications of these policy decisions. The roles and functions of MOPH (at the central, provincial and district levels) and of the autonomous health facilities and their interrelationships have yet to be adapted to these new strategies. MOPH also needs to define the extent and scope of hospital management autonomy, and the type of regulatory and control mechanisms required to ensure the provision of quality hospital services. Another major impediment is the overall shortage of qualified personnel within MOPH: the central level enjoys a significant number of qualified key staff but has a shortage of qualified medium-level staff, the provincial levels have an overall deficiency in personnel, in terms of both quantity and quality, and the entities soon to become autonomous lack the managerial capacity to assume their new functions. MOPH will strengthen, with donor support (Annex 4) its managerial and technical capacity required to: (i) design and implement its sector reforms; and (ii) empower the various stakeholders of the reforms to assume their new roles and responsibilities. 1.28 At the central level, capacity building will be provided through the recruitment of long term local consultants to assist MOPH in designing and implementing some of the reforms that the project will support (human resource management, health financing, and hospital managerial autonomy). These consultants would not only provide crucial input in designing and implementing reforms, but also train MOPH staff (especially medium-level staff), and strengthen existing capacities in policy analysis, planning and programming, as well as in specific technical areas (e.g., cost studies, public expenditure programming). MOPH staff will also receive the support of short and long term technical assistance and benefit from comprehensive training programs (including study tours abroad). At the provincial level, MOPH will first ensure that the 15 directors of the provincial bureaus assume their functions as provincial directors and relinquish clinical work at provincial hospitals. They will concentrate primarily on supervising their respective health facilities, especially those with few or no qualified personnel, and ensuring that health facilities have access to adequate human and financial resources through appropriate redistribution of such resources within the province. The staffing of the provincial health bureaus (BPS) will increase only gradually, as resources permit. Donors will strengthen capacities of health staff at the provincial and district levels and in the new autonomous entities through extensive training programs and provision of external technical assistance (Annex 4). 1.29 Inadequacy of the rural hospital network. The conditions of health facilities have been summarized in paras. 1.10 and 1.11. Most provincial and "secteur" hospitals are unable to deliver adequate curative services and backstop health centers in the provision of primary health care. Buildings are in poor condition and most equipment needs to be replaced. Although more Government resources are allocated to hospitals than to health centers, provincial and "secteur"
 10 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project hospitals have never received a fair share of resources when compared with hospitals in Bujumbura. Shortages of physicians (particularly specialists) and a lack of consumable supplies have always been a critical issue (patients are sometimes referred to Bujumbura even for X-rays). These hospitals have also been poorly managed, with no incentives to become efficient. MOPH has elaborated a rehabilitation plan covering all 26 public provincial and "secteur" hospitals (Annex 6). Rehabilitation works were initiated a few years ago and will continue with the support of several donors, including IDA through the proposed project. MOPH also intends to extend management autonomy to all public hospitals by the year 1997. 1.30 Rapid population growth. The growth of the population of Burundi is one of its most important constraints to development. With a current growth rate of 3.1% per year (up from 2% during 1975-80), the population will double in 25 years. The total fertility rate is estimated at 6.8 children per woman, which is above the SSA average of 6.4. Nearly half the population (47%) is under 15. Burundi will continue to face a high dependency ratio (close to 1) over the next few decades if this trend remains constant. Despite political leaders' awareness, a major gap has existed between official declarations and actions taken: the current family planning program has lacked Government support and the modem contraceptive prevalence rate (MCPR) is still only 1.6%. The recent crisis has resulted in delaying the implementation of important efforts toward reform: (i) the population policy statement, drafted in October 1992, has still not been ratified; and (ii) the national population council (CONAPO), which was to oversee the implementation of this policy, has not yet been established. Long a high priority, population control has become a particularly sensitive issue since the crisis; it is therefore difficult to anticipate the timing of these reforms. However, continued potential exists to expand family planning services, as shown in the 1987 Demographic and Health Survey. Donors, including IDA (Annex 4), will help MOPH implement its Medium-Term Family Planning Program; this program, prepared in 1993, has targeted an MCPR of 10% by 1997; however, this goal is over-optimistic in light of subsequent political events. 1.31 The Impact of the AIDS Epidemic. The Government was slow in responding to the AiDS challenge; the National AIDS Control Program (PNLS) was set up as late as 1988. However, as mortality from present infections rises, policy makers in many sectors will be forced to confront the specter of AIDS. The estimated 100,000 AIDS deaths that could occur between now and the year 2005 will be concentrated among Burundians who are urban dwellers (although eventually rural mortality will predominate), more educated, and female (urban women are infected at twice the rate of men). Past gains in child survival will decreased and the number of orphans is projected to increase from 18,000 to 90,000 by the year 2005. Under the PNLS, a medium-term plan and multisectoral strategy to address AIDS issues have been developed, supported by a multi-donor effort. However, the scope of the disease will require greater investment in coming years to educate the population, distribute condoms and control STD. Given the availability of grant funds, the Government has not requested financing from IDA to help implement the plan and strategy. However, the proposed project could provide indirect support to this effort by strengthening related IEC activities. In addition, as a part of its sector work, the Bank has started working with the Government in conducting an assessment of the socioeconomic impact of AIDS; this exercise may influence the Government's assessment of the adequacy of the current level of effort. Reallocation of project financing for AIDS-related activities could be considered at the mid-term review if needed. 1.32 Limited IEC Capacities. Successful in 1989-1991, IEC activities have since been hampered by serious problems. At the central level, the planning and coordination unit is now very weak and unable to efficiently plan and coordinate the IEC activities of many vertical or semi- vertical programs; this problem is further compounded by the absence of personnel trained in IEC at
 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project 11 the provincial and community levels. The lack of IEC capacity prevents delegation by the central office, which has instead to carry out all the activities itself in lieu of planning, coordinating and supervising them. As a result, the central office staff is overburdened and unable to respond to the demands of all programs. Programs which used to work with HEU until recently thus have a tendency to carry out their own activities independently, which creates severe coordinating problems. This situation has tended to erode the progress made over the last few years. An analysis of the country's IEC situation carried out during project preparation shows HEU to be in a critical state. The main problems are: (a) at the central level: a lack of specialized skills, especially in management and planning, but also in research and evaluation; and too much emphasis on material production, rather than on planning, coordination, technical assistance, supervision and quality control; (b) at the provincial level, a lack of trained personnel to supervise IEC field activities, and to train IEC personnel; and (c) at the community level, a lack of capacities to carry out IEC activities, either in the community or in the health centers. Inability to carry out good communications campaigns hampers the efforts of MOPH to improve public knowledge about individual self-care and beneficial health behaviors, including contraceptive behaviors. Lack of research capacity results in a poor understanding of health problems by the public, and policy makers' inability to take account of the target audiences' points of view. Without this capacity, the family planning program would be unable to reach its objective.

Starting in September 1994, the Government of Burundi with IDA support prepared an Emergency Recovery Program (ERP) for 1995 to finance the immediate needs of priority sectors, including health. Its total cost is US$53 million, of which US$15.5 million is for health (the outline of the program for the health sector is given in Annex 4). The Government of Burundi has submitted the ERP to various donors, including IDA, which approved in December 1994 a US$14.6 million Emergency Assistance Credit (Cr. 2668-BI). Of this amount, US$6 million should be spent for the health sector. The Emergency Assistance Credit became effective in April 1995. This aid, together with that to be provided by other donors, should cover the financing needed for the sector's rehabilitation program in 1995; the European Union has committed to contribute US$5.3 million in 1995, and other donors are also providing significant support to help rebuild Burundi's health system (Annex 4). 2.2 The Government's sector strategies. Beyond the transition phase of restoring health services, the Government wants to introduce the structural reforms which are urgently required to make the system operate more effectively and equitably and respond better to the needs of the population. Most of these reforms had been defined prior to the crisis but need to be refined in line with the new country situation. The Government intends to develop the following strategies: (i) decentralize the health system, by giving management autonomy to public hospitals and provincial health bureaus (BPS), and later to health centers, and by strengthening their capabilities; (ii) develop a human resource policy to reduce the acute shortage of medical personnel; (iii) improve the performance and equity of existing health care financing mechanisms; (iv) improve drug availability and affordability, by developing an essential drug policy and establishing an autonomous essential drug procurement unit; (v) strengthen basic health services and hospitals in peripheral areas; (vi) control public health problems, such as AIDS; and (vii) implement innovative family planning strategies, as a way to control population growth. The Government has, as a condition of Board presentation, submitted a signed sector policy letter, including an action plan and timetable, acceptable to IDA, which is presented at Annex 7 (para. 7.3 (a)). 2.3 Other donors' activities. The country's main donors have made a commitment to assist MOPH in implementing its key strategies over the next few years (Annex 4). The European Union will support the strengthening of the BPS; initial and in-service training for paramedical personnel; and pharmaceutical sector reform, including the establishment of an autonomous drug procurement unit. The European Union, Belgium, France and Germany will finance the rehabilitation of provincial and "secteur" hospitals. In addition, WHO, UNICEF, UNDP and Belgium will support the strengthening of basic health services and public health programs, while UNFPA and Germany will continue to support the implementation of the population policy. Finally, a multi-donor effort is supporting Burundi's national AIDS program. The high quality of current donor coordination is a result of the commendable efforts made by MOPH throughout 1993 and 1994. The Government has committed itself, in its sector policy letter, to maintain the existing aid coordination mechanisms, including regular quarterly meetings with donors to review the implementation of sector reforms.

The CAS is being presented to the Executive Directors on May 25, 1995 with the proposed project. The proposed CAS aims to help Burundi avert a socio-political breakdown and lay the foundations for economic recovery and diversified growth, with a view to increasing employment opportunities and improving equity, mainly through productivity gains in agriculture and increased access to social services. The broad reform agenda focuses on the following: (i) increased equity and better governance; (ii) environmentally sustainable, accelerated growth based on private sector development; and (iii) human resource development through better quality of, and increased access to, education and health services, and reduced demographic growth. The proposed project is a central part of the CAS and is included in all three alternative lending scenarios which are proposed in the CAS (Best-effort, Social-core and Disengagement). The Bank's assistance to the social sectors in Burundi started in 1977. There are two ongoing projects: the Population and Health Project and the Education Sector Development Project, which have sought to improve basic health and education services. They both started in 1988 and will both be completed by the end of 1995. A Social Action Project (FY93) was further initiated to improve living conditions among the poor and vulnerable groups through subprojects of a social fund aimed at improved productivity, enhanced access to social services, and increased employment opportunities. A new education project is being prepared. In addition, sector work (FY95-96) is being conducted with the Government on the socio-economic impact of AIDS. 2.5 The proposed project would form an integral part of the Government's and the Bank's strategies, helping the Government to: (i) strengthen MOPH capacity to effect sector reforms, including the system's ability to provide quality services affordable to the poor and respond adequately to the public's expectations; and (ii) improve the quality and efficiency of health care delivery in rural areas. It will also assist the Government in implementing its maternal and child health, family planning and IEC policies, targeting reduced population growth and improved health and family planning behaviors. Along with other donor interventions, the proposed project would constitute a coordinated and joint effort to support the Government's health sector strategies It would complement the efforts of the ongoing health project to strengthen health centers, which represent the primary level of health care delivery. C. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PAST PROJECTS 2.6 IDA's ongoing Population and Health Project (Cr. 1862-BI, US$14 million, approved in FY 1988) will be completed by June 30, 1995. Project objectives were to improve maternal and child health by strengthening such services and nutrition activities, on a nationwide basis. The project is progressing well towards its overall stated objectives. However, efforts to strengthen family planning services and design health financing strategies suffered from a lack of Government commitment and weak institutional capacity; these two areas will be addressed under the proposed project. Project implementation in Burundi has been generally satisfactory in terms of procurement and disbursement rates. The main lessons learned from the first project are the following: (a) a project is better implemented when the Government is committed, when key MOPH staff are involved in project design and preparation, and when beneficiary opinions are taken into account during project preparation; (b) managerial and institutional capacities to develop project activities need to be carefully assessed during project preparation and adequate strengthening must be provided throughout project implementation; (c) strengthening health centers is not enough to ensure an improvement in overall health service delivery; (d) rehabilitation activities should
 14 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project emphasize equally physical and qualitative inputs and outputs (increased service capacity and quality); and (e) key functions, such as project coordination, procurement and accounting need to be strengthened. Another major lesson learned from the implementation of such projects in other countries is that the transfer of health policy and management responsibility to decentralized levels and autonomous entities needs to be gradual and accompanied by adequate transfers of authority and financial, physical and human resources. 2.7 The design of the proposed project has incorporated all these lessons by: (a) involving MOPH officials and high-level staff in project design and preparation, and carrying out beneficiary assessment during project preparation (other assessments will be conducted throughout project implementation); (b) requesting a draft letter of sector policy that could serve as a monitoring tool during annual and mid-term reviews; (c) recruiting high-level local consultants qualified in areas of MOPH deficiency; (d) rehabilitating hospitals to improve their capacity to backstop the first level of care; (e) ensuring that, within three months of being granted autonomy, public hospitals have adopted the related regulations and by-laws and that, within six months after their rehabilitation, project hospitals have introduced management accounting systems and training programs in hospital management, and have sufficient staffing; (f) strengthening coordination, procurement and accounting functions within the PCT; and (g) ensuring progressive management autonomy for hospitals and BPS, with transfer of adequate material and financial resources and strengthening of their management capacities.

The project was appraised in May 1993 but negotiations could not take place because of the October 1993 events. The installation of a new Government in September 1994 enabled various donors, including IDA, to redefine and coordinate their activities in the sector. The project was re-appraised in December 1994. Its content has been redefined on the basis of the new priorities of MOPH and other donors' interventions. The project and the contributions of other donors (Annex 4) together constitute a coherent program to support the Government in its efforts to develop and implement all the sector strategies defined in its sector policy letter. 3.2 The objectives of the proposed Second Health and Population Project are to improve the health status of Burundi's population and contribute to sustainable per capita growth by slowing population growth, thus reducing population pressures on resources. The project aims to do this by increasing the availability, quality and efficiency of health services and making them more responsive to the public's expectations. Specific objectives are to: (i) strengthen MOPH's capacity to design and implement key sector reforms; (ii) improve the availability and quality of health care delivery in rural areas; (iii) contribute to reducing population growth and maternal and child mortality rates; and (iv) promote beneficial health and family planning behaviors. Project components consist of: (i) strengthening MOPH's capacity to effect key sector reforms in human resource management, hospital management autonomy, health financing, quality of health services, and maintenance; (ii) strengthening service delivery in five out of 15 provinces, by supporting basic health services and rehabilitating nine hospitals; (iii) implementing the maternal and child and family planning (MCH/FP) policy; and (iv) improving IEC activities. 3.3. Given the country's current political situation, the project has been designed in a flexible manner to permit the implementation of certain activities even in a context of a renewed political crisis and insecurity in certain parts of the country. Rehabilitation of project hospitals would be done in three phases that would be modified according to the prevailing state of security, starting with hospitals located in the safest provinces. Likewise, management autonomy and health service quality would first be strengthened in these hospitals. Implementation of MCH/FP policy and IEC activities at the provincial and community levels also would first be carried out in the safest areas of the country. Activities to support design and implementation of sector reforms would be the most affected by a renewed crisis, although some reforms (such as implementing strategies to reduce shortage of health personnel and strengthening hospital management autonomy) could be tailored and implemented more quickly to address a new crisis. However, reforms aimed at improving existing financing mechanisms and redeploying health personnel could be delayed, since they involve political decisions or actions that may not be feasible in an aggravated crisis. In case of a continuous crisis, the project would be restructured substantially as needed during the mid-term review. Finally, it was agreed with MOPH and other donors that flexibility would be introduced in the project's financing to address emerging new sector priorities, as well as permit eventual co-financing from other donors during implementation. Existing aid coordination mechanisms, including quarterly meetings with donors, will permit regular updating of sector priorities and reallocation of donor support if necessary.

DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT Component 1: Institutional Strengthening Total Cost: US$7.7 million IDA Contribution: US$5.3 million 3.4 Human resource development and management. The main objective is to assist MOPH in designing and implementing strategies to reduce the current shortage of medical personnel and correct the geographical imbalance in the distribution of such personnel. These strategies would include: (i) annual recruitment of new graduates; (ii) redeployment of personnel, based on the demand for, as well as individual preferences of, health personnel; (iii) payment of travel-related allowances to paramedical personnel willing to work on temporary assignments in the most insecure areas of the country; (iv) short-term recruitment of expatriate physicians, if possible from within the region, to provide emergency replacement technical assistance; (v) negotiation of contracts with private religious health facilities for the management of health centers in hardship areas; and (vi) support for initial and in-service training of medical personnel. Given the crucial importance of the issue, the MOPH intends to start designing some of the strategies in 1995, with PPF financing. The proposed project would result in the following outcomes: (i) a redeployment plan would be designed by mid-1996; (ii) existing health staff would be redeployed by the end of 1997; and (iii) personnel needs, as defined by MOPH, would be fulfilled by the year 2000 (Annex 8). 3.5 As preliminary tasks, the MOPH will carry out with PPF support a thorough inventory of active personnel, by health facility and province, and a survey of the medical personnel who are currently not at their posts. It will then assess priority staffing needs over the next five years. A human resource committee composed of key MOPH officials in charge of directorates and programs has been set up to lead these activities. The Government would submit to IDA for its review a detailed assessment of total personnel needs within the public health sector as a condition of credit effectiveness (para. 7.4(a)). Staffing needs for physicians in the nine project hospitals have been estimated on the basis of their current staffing (both national and expatriate). It was assumed that half the number of additional physicians needed would be Burundi nationals recruited by MOPH and the other half would be expatriate physicians, financed under the proposed project. These needs will be reassessed shortly in the context of a detailed study on the current situation of the nine hospitals, to be carried out under PPF financing (para. 3.22). The project would ensure that the adequate number of health personnel would be assigned by MOPH to the nine project hospitals (para 3.23). Paramedicals who would be willing to work in insecure areas would be given a per diem (as a travel-related allowance) per day spent away from their current place of residence. The staff would be asked to work four-five days in these areas and would return either each night or each weekend to their current place of residence. These allowances would be time-bound and would be eliminated as these areas return to more stability. These allowances have been calculated at one-third of MOPH approved per diem rates for civil servants (i.e. 500 FBu, or US$2/day).  30 Burundi: Second Health and Population Project V. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION A. STATUS OF PROJECT PREPARATION AND READINESS 5.1 The proposed project was identified in February 1991. Project preparation was carried out with financial support from the ongoing Population and Health Project (Cr. 1862-BI) and a Japanese PHRD Grant. A beneficiary assessment was carried out during project preparation to determine beneficiaries' satisfaction with Burundi's public health services, including the pre- payment health card (CAM). Appraisal took place in May 1993 and post-appraisal in September 1993. Project negotiations were scheduled to be completed by end-1993 but could not take place because of the October 1993 events. The establishment of a new Government in September 1994 made possible a re-appraisal mission in November/December 1994. The content of the project was redefined on the basis of MOPH's new priorities and other donor interventions; main donors participated in the re-appraisal of the project. Some project activities were maintained and redefined, such as: improvement of sector financing, introduction of management autonomy for hospitals, hospital rehabilitation, and implementation of the IEC policy. New activities have been added, including: development and management of human resources, quality management and assessment, and implementation of the MCH/FP policy. During the re-appraisal mission, it was agreed with MOPH that activities aimed at establishing an autonomous drug procurement unit would not be financed through the proposed project, given European Union commitment to their financing. Since the on-going Population and Health Project will be closing on June 30, 1995, the Government requested a PPF totaling US$670,000 to continue preparatory activities so that project activities are ready to start by the time the proposed credit becomes effective. The following activities are in the process of being completed: (a) action plans for implementing sector reforms to be supported by the proposed project have been prepared; (b) architectural designs and tender documents for hospital rehabilitation have been finalized; and (c) lists of equipment, furniture and vehicles are being finalized. The details of equipment needs (including specifications and quantities) for the 19 health centers and nine hospitals to be supported by the proposed project would be reassessed based on new priorities and staffing constraints, through an evaluation study scheduled to be done before credit effectiveness; detailed terms of reference for this study have already been prepared. This study would not lead to an increase in cost estimates but to a rescheduling of equipment supply (para. 3.22). B. MANAGEMENT AND COORDINATION 5.2 The MOPH would have overall responsibility for project implementation. All project activities would be managed and implemented by existing units or directorates within MOPH, as follows: (i) activities related to human resource development and management would be managed by the Directorate for Health Services, in cooperation with DGS for training activities; (ii) the introduction of management autonomy for public hospitals would be managed and supervised by the IGS (Inspection Generale de la Sante), in cooperation with the DGS for training activities; (iii) all activities linked to improving health financing mechanisms would be managed by the Unit in charge of Planning and Coordination of Studies, Program and Budget; (iv) activities related to quality assessment and management would be carried out by the IGS; (v) implementation of the maintenance strategy would be supervised by the Directorate for Health Logistics; (vi) all project activities related to the strengthening of service delivery in five provinces would be managed by the DGS, in cooperation with the Directorate for Health Logistics; (vii) maternal and child health and

BENEFITS 6.1 The rehabilitation of health services and the implementation of key sector reforms with regard to health personnel, health financing and hospital management would contribute to improving the overall quality of health services in Burundi, while making them more accessible to the poor, at an affordable cost. The project is therefore expected to help reduce the country's mortality and morbidity rates. In addition, the successful implementation of the family planning policy and IEC activities would help Burundi reduce its population growth rate and promote beneficial health behaviors among the population. The project would have the following expected benefits: (i) quality of health services in the project area would be judged satisfactory by 60% of the beneficiaries surveyed at the end of the project; (ii) efficiency of the health care delivery system would increase; (iii) management autonomy would have been introduced in all public hospitals, with management systems and skills strengthened; (iv) overall sector financing would increase; (v) modem contraceptive prevalence would increase from 1.6% now to 10% by the year 2000; and (vi) IEC programs would contribute to more efficient use of health services and greater health coverage. Using the letter of sector policy as a monitoring tool, the project would also assess annual progress made in the implementation of complementary reforms that would be accomplished with other donors' support, such as decentralization and strengthening of the health administration and improvement of drug availability, management and use. B. RISKS 6.2 This is a project with above-average risk. The main risk relates to the country's unstable political situation; to address this risk, the project has been designed in a flexible manner, so that some components could be implemented even during a crisis and the project's intended benefits could be safeguarded; for example, hospital rehabilitation, implementation of MCH/FP and IEC activities, and strengthening of hospital management autonomy could be implemented first in the safest provinces. However, implementation of some sector reforms (particularly health financing and staff redeployment) could be delayed, since they involve political decisions and actions that may not be feasible in a crisis situation. In case of a continuous crisis, the project would be restructured substantially as needed during the mid-term review. Other risks relate to (ii) the population's response to MOPH's reforms; to address this risk, a beneficiary assessment has been conducted and the results used during project preparation; similar assessments and quality surveys would be carried out throughout project implementation; (iii) the institutional weaknesses of MOPH,' to address this risk, project support would include strong capacity-building activities in areas where MOPH lacks expertise; project implementation would be divided among different directorates within MOPH, while PCT procurement and financial functions would be strengthened; and the project conditions would enable close monitoring of project implementation and development performance; (iv) the weak human resource base, especially the lack of qualified health personnel; to address this risk, the project would help MOPH reduce the overall deficiency of personnel, in terms of both quantity and quality; and (v) insufficient MOPH funding, which may jeopardize the improvement of health services; to address this risk, Government agreed at negotiations that its proposals for health sector investments and budgetary allocations would be reviewed by IDA annually and that the draft budget would incorporate IDA's comments before its approval by the Council of Ministers.

doc.repnme: Burundi - Second Health and Population Project
doc.abstracts: The Second Health and Population Project will improve the health status of Burundi's population and contribute to sustainable per capita income growth by slowing population growth, thus reducing population pressures on resources. It will help increase the availability, quality and efficiency of health services and make them more responsive to the public's expectations. Together with the contributions of other donors, the project will constitute a coherent program to support the government in developing strategies to address the most critical sector issues. Specifically the project will: (i) strengthen the Ministry of Public Health's capacity to design and implement key sector reforms; (ii) improve the efficiency and affordability of health care delivery in rural areas; (iii) contribute to reducing population growth and maternal and child mortality rates; and (iv) promote beneficial health and family planning behaviors.
